facts.text: Appellants are owners of China Baug situated on the southern bank of the river Sabarmati within the limits of the Municipal Corporation of Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are owners of China Baug situated on the southern bank of the river Sabarmati within the limits of the Municipal Corporation of Ahmedabad.

facts.text: Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation resolved to move the State Government to acquire a part of the land of the appellants for setting up a Samadhi of Mahatma Gandhi.

anchor.surface_text: The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation resolved to move the State Government to acquire a part of the land of the appellants for setting, up a Samadlyi of Mahatma Gandhi.

facts.text: On September 10, 1959, the Commissioner, Ahmedabad Division, in the State of Bombay, issued a notification under S. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: On September 10, 1959, the Commissioner. Ahmedabad Division, in the State of Bombay, issued a numberification under S. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act, stating Whereas it appears to the Commissioner,

facts.text: Notification under S.4 stated lands likely needed for public purpose viz. for The Memorial of Rashtrapita Mahatma Gandhi.

anchor.surface_text: stating Whereas it appears to the Commissioner, Ahmedabad Division, that the lands specified in the schedule hereto are likely to be needed for public purpose viz. for The Memorial of Rashtrapita Mahatma Gandhi

facts.text: Enquiry was made under s. 5A of the Land Acquisition Act and report received from the Collector.

anchor.surface_text: Enquiry was made under s. 5A of the Land Acquisition Act and after receiving the report of the Collector,

facts.text: On August 31, 1961, the Commissioner, Baroda Division of the State of Gujarat issued a notification under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: the Commissioner. Baroda Division of the State of Gujarat  who by virtue of the Bombay Reorganization Act, 1960, was the appropriate authority  issued a numberification under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act on August 31, 1961,

facts.text: Notification under S.6 declared lands required for public purpose: Memorial of Mahatma Gandhi.

anchor.surface_text: that the lands were required for the public purpose specified in companyumn 4 of the schedule to the numberification i.e. Memorial of Mahatma Gandhi.

facts.text: Appellants moved a petition in the High Court of Gujarat: Special Civil Application No. 622 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants moved a petition in the High Court of Gujarat for a writ quashing the proceeding under the Land Acquisition Act and the two numberifications dated September 10, 1959 and August 31, 1961

facts.text: High Court petition sought quashing of proceedings under Land Acquisition Act and notifications dated September 10, 1959 and August 31, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants moved a petition in the High Court of Gujarat for a writ quashing the proceeding under the Land Acquisition Act and the two numberifications dated September 10, 1959 and August 31, 1961 and for a writ restraining the Commissioner.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court rejected the petition on July 28, 29, 30, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated July 28, 29, 30. 1965 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 622 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court: Civil Appeal No. 1102 of 1967 with certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) granted by High Court.

facts.text: Bombay Reorganization Act, 1960 made Commissioner Baroda Division the appropriate authority.

anchor.surface_text: the Commissioner. Baroda Division of the State of Gujarat  who by virtue of the Bombay Reorganization Act, 1960, was the appropriate authority

facts.text: Legislature of State of Bombay enacted Commissioners of Divisions Act 8 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature of the State of Bombay enacted the Commissioners of Divisions Act 8 of 1958.

facts.text: Government of State of Bombay issued notification on September 5, 1958 under s. 3(4) of Commissioners of Divisions Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of the State of Bombay issued on September 5, 1958 a numberification under s. 3 4  of the Commissioners of Divisions Act,

facts.text: Land notified under s.4: 3428 sq. yards 3 sq. ft. out of Survey No. 348B, and 494 sq. yards 5 sq. ft. out of Survey No. 349.

anchor.surface_text: The land numberified for acquisition under s. 4 was 3428 sq. yards 3 sq. ft. out of Survey No. 348B, and 494 sq. yards 5 sq. ft. out. of Survey No. 349.

facts.text: Land under s.6: 3562 sq. yards out of Survey No. 348B and 387 sq. yards out of Survey No. 349.

anchor.surface_text: The area of the land numberified under s. 6 was stated to be 3562 sq. yards out of Survey No. 348B and 387 sq. yards out of Survey No. 349.

facts.text: In s.6 notification, remaining area of Survey No. 348B notified under s.4 declared abandoned.

anchor.surface_text: Even though the area of land out of Survey No. 348B exceeded the area originally mentioned in the numberification under s. 4, the Commissioner stated in the impugned numberification that the remaining area of the said lands numberified under section 4 is hereby abandoned.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court in SCA 800/1961 held failure to mention instrumentality invalidates notification.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 800 of 1961. Chandulal Patel v. The State of Gujarat held that if the public purpose for which land is numberified for acquisition is to be executed through ,In instrumentality other than the State Government , failure to specifically mention the instrumentality in the numberifications rends numberification invalid.

facts.text: Full Bench Gujarat HC in Ramji Popatbhai v. Jamnadas overruled earlier judgment on instrumentality.

anchor.surface_text: But in Ramji Popatbhai v. Jamnadas sha a Full Bench of the High Court has overruled that earlier  1   1969  Guj. L.R. 164. slp. C.I./70-13 judgment.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra held s.3(4) of Commissioners Act not excessive delegation.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has in Arnold Rodricks Anr. v. State of Maharashtra Ors.  1  by majority held that the powers companyferred by s. 3  4  on the State Governments are number unguided and that the State Legislature has by enacting S. 3  4  number abdicated its powers

facts.text: Supreme Court in Vishnu Prasad Ramdas Gohil v. State of Gujarat held failure to specify instrumentality does not invalidate notifications.

anchor.surface_text: In Vishnu Prasad Ramdas Gohil Others v. The State of Gujarat 1  we have held, agreeing with the view of the Full Bench of the Gujarat High Court, that failure to specify the instrumentality which is to execute the public purpose does number affect the validity of the numberification either under S. 4 or under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 800 of 1961 Chandulal Patel v. The State of Gujarat held that if the public purpose... failure to specifically mention the instrumentality... renders notification invalid. But in Ramji Popatbhai v. Jamnadas a Full Bench... has overruled that earlier judgment.

holdings.text: The challenge to the vires of the Commissioners of Divisions Act 8 of 1958 must fail.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has in Arnold Rodricks Anr. v. State of Maharashtra Ors. 1 by majority held that the powers conferred by s. 3 4 on the State Governments are not unguided and that the State Legislature has by enacting S. 3 4 not abdicated its powers... The challenge to the vires of the Commissioners of Divisions Act 8 of 1958 must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows majority precedent in Arnold Rodricks v. State of Maharashtra upholding s.3(4) as not excessive delegation since legislative policy laid down.

holdings.text: The Commissioner of Baroda Division was competent to issue notification under s.6 without fresh s.4 notification.

anchor.surface_text: But after the notification was issued, the State of Bombay was reorganized and the area in which the land is situated was included in the new State of Gujarat. The Commissioner of Baroda Division was competent to exercise the powers under the Commissioners of Divisions Act which continued to remain in force...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-reorganization under Bombay Reorganization Act, 1960, authority transferred; original s.4 valid, no requirement for fresh s.4.

holdings.text: No precondition to attempt acquisition by agreement under s.77 PMC Act before invoking s.78; s.78 provides alternative acquisition route.

anchor.surface_text: Section 77 of the Provincial Municipal Corporations Act... Section 78(1) provides... There is nothing in ss. 77(1) 78(1) which supports the contention that before initiation of a proceeding for acquisition... must start negotiations for purchase by private agreement...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language of s.78(1) indicates alternative, not conditioned on failed s.77 negotiations; no mandatory sequence.

holdings.text: Setting up a memorial to Mahatma Gandhi constitutes a public purpose under Land Acquisition Act independent of municipal purposes under PMC Act.

anchor.surface_text: The land is needed for setting up a memorial to Mahatma Gandhi at a place associated with him, and we regard, because of the universal veneration in which the memory of Mahatma Gandhi is held in our country, that the purpose was a public purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Memorial at associated place serves public purpose due to national veneration; no reliance needed on extended PMC s.78 definition.

holdings.text: Land Acquisition Act does not require specification of instrumentality executing public purpose in s.4 or s.6 notifications.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory silence; follows own precedent in Vishnu Prasad and Gujarat Full Bench in Ramji Popatbhai overruling earlier SCA 800/1961.

holdings.text: Commissioner, Baroda Division applied mind in issuing s.6 notification; area discrepancy does not indicate non-application.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Area under s.6 slightly larger but excess over s.4 abandoned; only part of survey notified under s.4, recital explained.

holdings.text: Notification under s.6 is conclusive evidence that land needed for public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: We may observe that a notification issued under s. 6 is by sub-s. 3 conclusive evidence that the land is needed for a public purpose.
